p.s: The author Angie Thomas makes use of means of point of view and differenddifferend narrative techniques in order to present Starr's state of mind.
First, the given text extract is told by a first-person-protagonist-narrator, who is Starr Carter.
Starr told the story from her own perspective which means that she has a limited point of view.
This first-person-protagonist-narrator helps the reader to feel Starr's situation and for him it feels like he is a part of the crowd.
Furthermore the author Angie Thomas makes use of differenddifferend narrative techniques.
First of all, the text is written in a mode which makes the reader think he is a part of the situation because all is told detailed.
Besides, the author makes use of a flashback (ll. 6-7, ll. 19-22) which is split in two sections.
This flashback remindreminds the reader to the dramatic scene where Khalil got shot by the police officer and pointpoints out again the dramatic circumstances.
Moreover there are many interior monologesmonologues (cf. ll. 43-44, cf. l. 48) which state how much tension is in Starr.
This brings the reader more in Starr's thoughts and feelings which helps the reader to be closer to the situation.
Furthermore there is a flash-forward at the end (cf. l. 56) to underline that they will keep protesting, when the police doesn't give them a reason to think otherwise.
This has also an effect on the reader, who now wantwants to know whether it will be better or not.
At the end, the author makes use again of a flashback to emphasize that Khalil lived and could still live if the anariu doesn't have so a big problem with racism.
All in all, the author presents Starr's state of mind in a way, that the reader feelfeels he is a part of this extract and he was in the crowd as participant.
